Ray V wrote:
> I'm relatively new to JUnit, but I've started to use
> it a bit, and now I'm faced with a project where I
> think it could provide a lot of value.  I could use
> some advice.
> 
> Some background: I've come into a project that has no
> test coverage and has some pretty aggregious code...
> meanwhile new features are being slowly added.  The
> thing feels like it's on the verge of imploding, and
> this is the calm before the storm.
> 
> I'm going through the process right now of adding test
> cases, but as I write them I'm constantly fighting the
> urge to fix stuff.  My question: is it better to write
> all the tests first, then go back to fixing what's
> broken, or to fix the bugs and "smelly" code as you go?

Let me assume that I get to choose, meaning that no-one is exerting 
pressure on me to do one or the other. In that case, I prefer to fix the 
bugs/smells as I go. Here's an example why:

Suppose I have the same broken code in five places. It might not even be 
exactly the same code, but it's very similar. I'll use tests to help 
identify the problem in one place, then fix it there. Later, I'll use 
tests to identify the same problem somewhere else, so I fix it there, 
too. Now I get a nagging feeling that the same problem is in multiple 
places. If I hunt them down and the code looks similar enough, I'll 
sprinkle the area with enough tests to be able to replace the broken 
duplicate code with a call to the new working code.

If I had just written all the tests first, I wouldn't have seen the 
shortcut of fixing the "5 times" problem only three times, where the 
third time is "once and for all".

In general, tidying up as you go, especially in code with a lot of 
duplication, takes longer to get going, but allows you to accelerate. 
Before long you notice that code you thought you'd have to fix can 
actually just be deleted! (That's the best way to fix code: remove it.)

THAT SAID, if someone is putting pressure on you to expose bugs, rather 
than fix them, then I recommend just adding the tests and fixing things 
later. You can /try/ to explain to the pressure-applier that the cost 
will be roughly equal doing it either way, but let that person decide. 
There's no point in contradicting that person and then making him look 
bad. :)
